content:
Edited to fix the stub (message:word -> string) and set a more realistic bound on N (â‰¤1000 -> 10) in the constraints.

Not all languages provide an easy support of unicode, you should avoid non ASCII chars in inputs/outputs.

This would probably be interesting in shortest mode too.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The description is very clear. The challenge is fun. The test cases are sufficient.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good task for clash of code

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The clash is fun, not too hard and interresting

Perhaps add a constraint on the line length, it might be important in some programming languages which don't have easy dynamic strings. This could allow some programmers to more easily allocate a block to hold the line.
e.g. A line is not longer than 250 characters (excluding line end).

Not sure that your solution needs to split and rejoin words. Also, the default translation case needs only to return the  original value, not re-encode the ascii.
Sorry this feedback is not relevant to improving the puzzle, feel free to ignore :-)

Perhaps change the "Hi Bob" message to something more interesting like:
Hi Bob, how are you? it's looking nice for our evening out, can't wait! xoxo -Alice. <3 <3 <3

Hi, the statement can be simplified a little.
** PERHAPS you could change the puzzle to always write a security message *at the end*, e.g. either "Message secured." or "Not a secure message.". And you could customise the definition of "secure" for the puzzle, e.g. At least 50% of the characters in the message (excluding newlines) are modified.

How about the following simplified version:

Alice and Bob have a secret code, where each letter is swapped symmetrically (A and Z, B and Y, etc; similarly for lower case).
Help Bob decrypt Alice's messages.
** PLUS Bob would like to know if the message is secure or not... **

Change N to be "number of *lines in the message*"

Give an example that shows that other characters are not changed, e.g:

2
1. Secret plan 2B ("Termination") :- 
    Deploy items #325 & #45

"Any other characters will be remained." is confusing. I think you mean only a-z and A-Z will be changed, but at the moment, it reads that only "a" (lower case) and "B" (uppercase) will be changed.

Validators should test the same test cases as the associated test. For example, if the validator contains an accented character ("Ã©"), the test should too. You currently have validators named "test", which are not actual validators.
Thanks for your comment. So, as I understood, the validators will not be shown to the coder, right ?

It's very nice to here your comments <3
The puzzle is updated ;)
P/s : very sr about my bad english :P
thanks so much for the very nice comment !

No worries. Additionally:
A one word security message would be either "Secure" or "Insecure" - not "Secured" or "Unsecured".
Your example "a will be transformed to z ... zY" is fairly lame sorry :-) consider my "Hi Bob" example below as a replacement.
what do you think about the last updated version ? ðŸ˜‰
Correct, only a pass / fail for the validator (not even a reason for their failure).
